title: Why do people hate Christmas music? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll give a perspective of someone who only heard this “Christmas music” for the first time in adulthood. Personally, I don't hate Christmas music per se. I hate the ten or so specific Christmas songs every retailer feels obligated to play in a loop from late November. And I did not hate them the first ten times I had to listen to them. I did not like them (I generally don’t care for the 50s music, I can’t tell Bing Crosby from Buddy Holly, and I’ll take Pink Floyd over Elvis any time), but I did not hate them either. But, over time, they got old and then they got grating. And I started getting annoyed by the atonality of “little drummer boy”, or the ridiculousness of songs about “one-horse open sleighs” played when it’s 70 F outside, there’s not a single horse-drawn sleigh for hundreds of miles in any direction, and most of its listeners have never seen one except in pictures in any event. I’d be less peeved if they at least allowed some variety. Would it kill them to play “Wenceslas” or the Carol of the Bells once in a while (preferably in the rendition by the Trans-Siberian Orchestra, but I’m not picky?) Anything but the loop of “drummer boy” / “twelve days of christmas” / “jingle bells” / “jingle bell rock” / “silver bells”/“last christmas” / “silent night” and then back to start.

Personally at least, I don’t hate Christmas music. I hate the kind of Christmas music they play in public. It’s mostly very lounge-y, bland music that get very repetitive. Although there are many Christmas songs they play, due to genre choices it sounds like one really long one that just gets so incredibly old. They never play any classic Christmas carols, I can only assume because there aren’t many uber-famous covers of them, and instead they play much newer, much blander music. I don’t know, I kind of despise Michael Buble myself and that’s like, 86.7% of what they play. If anyone wants to know what kind of Christmas music I do like, by the way, it’s mostly carols, the Trans-Siberian Orchestra, and the H.P. Lovecraft Historical Society.
